newsitem.title: THAILAND: Bank of Thailand says no baht band widening.
newsitem.headline: Bank of Thailand says no baht band widening.

text.p: The Bank of Thailand on Friday dismissed rumours the central bank was planning to widen its dollar/baht trading band as "utter nonsense".
Paiboon Kittisrikangwan, the central bank's division chief in charge of money and foreign exchange markets, told Reuters the Bank of Thailand had no plan to change the exchange rate mechanism.
"Rumours about any change in the exchange rate mechanism, including band-widening, are utter nonsense," he said.

The baht was trading on the weak side on Thursday, precipitated by rumours that Thai authorities might be holding a meeting on the currency which could lead to a widening of the band, market sources said.
The Bank of Thailand's head of Banking Department Bandid Nijathavorn also said that the present trading band will not be changed.
"I wish to categorically deny that rumour and reiterate that the present trading band of plus and minus two satangs is to remain firmly in place," Bandid told Reuters.
"We are monitoring the baht market closely and will take necessary action to stabilise the external value of the baht," he said.
The baht is fixed against three major currencies in a trade-weighed basket dominated by the U.S. dollar.
The Bank of Thailand fixes a dollar/baht mid-rate on a daily basis. It buys the dollar two satangs below and sells two satangs above the mid-rate through commercial banks.
Analysts said Thailand's fixed currency and floating money market interest rates make baht susceptible to speculative market attacks, especially when the country faces a bearish economic outlook.
Thai authorities have said they are satisfied that the economy is respoding to monetary and fiscal measures.
They said inflation has been kept under control, current account deficit is narrowing and data from the customs department show signs of export recovery.
